withdraw: To withdraw cash from an ATM, insert your debit card, enter your 4-digit PIN, select 'Cash Withdrawal', choose the account type (e.g., Savings), and enter the desired amount.
deposit: To deposit cash, use a Cash Deposit Machine (CDM). Insert your card, select 'Deposit', place the cash in the tray when prompted, and confirm the amount. Some ATMs may not support deposits.
balance: To check your account balance, insert your card, enter your PIN, then select 'Balance Enquiry' from the options on the screen.
pin: If you've forgotten your ATM PIN, you can reset it via your bank's mobile app, internet banking, or by visiting the nearest branch.
limit: ATM withdrawal limits depend on your bank and card type, typically ranging from ₹10,000 to ₹50,000 per day. Some premium accounts may have higher limits.
card: If your card is lost, stolen, or damaged, block it immediately via your bank's customer care, app, or net banking, and request a replacement card.
receipt: To get a receipt, choose the 'Print Receipt' or 'Transaction Slip' option at the end of your ATM transaction.
language: Most ATMs allow you to select your preferred language on the welcome screen, including regional language options.
charges: Banks may offer 3–5 free ATM transactions per month. After that, a nominal fee is charged for additional transactions, depending on the bank.
account: ATMs typically support transactions for savings and current accounts linked to your debit card.
money: If an ATM is out of cash, it may display a message or fail to process the withdrawal. Try using another nearby ATM.
transaction: If your ATM transaction fails but your account is debited, the amount is usually reversed within 5 to 7 working days. Contact your bank if the issue persists.
support: For any ATM-related issues, call your bank's 24x7 customer care number. It’s usually printed on the ATM or your debit card.
fast cash: Fast Cash is a quick option to withdraw a preset amount (e.g., ₹500, ₹1000) without navigating through multiple menus.
mini statement: You can select 'Mini Statement' to view your recent transactions. The statement shows the last 5–10 entries from your account.

brain tumor: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain.
symptoms of brain tumor: Common symptoms include headaches, seizures, vision problems, and changes in memory or mood.
types of brain tumors: Brain tumors can be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous).
benign brain tumor: Benign brain tumors are non-cancerous and usually grow slowly without spreading to other parts.
malignant brain tumor: Malignant brain tumors are cancerous and can grow rapidly, spreading to other brain tissues.
brain tumor diagnosis: Diagnosis is done using MRI scans, CT scans, and sometimes biopsy procedures.
brain tumor treatment: Treatment may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of these.
brain tumor causes: The exact cause is unknown, but risk factors include genetic mutations, radiation exposure, and family history.
tumor prevention: There is no guaranteed way to prevent brain tumors, but reducing exposure to radiation and avoiding carcinogens can help.
types of tumors: Common brain tumors include gliomas, meningiomas, pituitary tumors, and schwannomas.
glioma: Gliomas are tumors that start in the glial cells of the brain or spine.
meningioma: Meningiomas arise from the meninges, the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.
pituitary tumor: Pituitary tumors grow in the pituitary gland and can affect hormone production.
brain tumor survival rate: Survival rates depend on tumor type, size, location, and treatment, but early detection generally improves outcomes.
brain tumor risk factors: Risk factors include age, exposure to radiation, genetic syndromes, and a family history of brain tumors.
